hwclock.purpose: Specify whether the hardware clock of your machine is set to local time or GMT.
hwclock.description:
<para> Most PCs that also have other operating systems installed (such as Microsoft Windows) use local time. Machines that have only Linux installed should be set to Greenwich Mean Time (GMT). If you are unsure, use GMT. </para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Values</title> <para> GMT or localtime </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>&alice; Compatibility</title> <para>This property is replaces the following tags in &alice; </para> <itemizedlist> <listitem><para><SYS_HWC_GMT></para></listitem> </itemizedlist>
</refsect2>

configure.purpose: Data for post-configuration after the system has been setup. This tag is deprecated since SUSE Linux 10.0
configure.description: <para> Data for post-configuration after the system has been setup. </para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Resource </para> </refsect2>

bootloader.description: <para> The directive handles the bootloader configuration. Using the vootloader element, theuser can specify where lilo should be installed and whether some hardware dependent parameters should be activated. </para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Resource </para> </refsect2>

encrypted.description:
<para> Specify whether the given password is encrypted. If the password is given in clear text, then it will be encrypted, otherwise it will be kept as is.
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Values</title> <para> This element takes a boolean as a value. Possible values are <emphasis>true</emphasis> or <emphasis>false</emphasis>. </para> </refsect2>

boot.purpose: Name of the device (e.g. a hard disk partition) that contains the boot sector.

lba32.purpose: Generate 32-bit Logical Block Addresses instead of sector/head/cylinder addresses.

menuscheme.purpose: Color scheme of the boot menu

message.purpose: specifies a file containing a message that is displayed before the boot prompt.

prompt.purpose: The boot loader will issue the boot: prompt and wait for user input before proceeding (see timeout TODO).

readonly.purpose: This specifies that the root file system should be mounted read- only.

timeout.purpose: Sets the timeout for timed messages
timeout.description: <para> Timeout before a message disappears. </para> <refsect2><title>Values</title> <para> Timeout in seconds. </para> </refsect2>

show.description: <para> Determine whether to show pop-up messages, warnings or erros. </para> <refsect2><title>Values</title> <para> boolean </para> </refsect2>

log.description: <para> Determine whether to log pop-up messages, warnings or erros. </para> <refsect2><title>Values</title> <para> boolean </para> </refsect2>

vga.purpose: This specifies the VGA text mode that should be selected when booting.
vga.description:
<para> See <emphasis>lilo.conf(5)</emphasis>
</para> <refsect2><title>Values</title> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <Para><emphasis>normal</emphasis>: select normal 80x25 text mode.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <Para><emphasis>extended (or ext)</emphasis>: select 80x50 text mode.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <Para><emphasis>ask</emphasis>: stop and ask for user input (at boot time).</para> </listitem> <listitem> <Para><emphasis><number></emphasis>: use the corresponding text mode. A list of available modes can be obtained by booting with <emphasis>>vga=ask</emphasis> and pressing [Enter]. </para> </listitem> </itemizedlist>
</refsect2>

root_login_remote.purpose: allow root logins from other machines
root_login_remote.description: <para> If you want to allow root logins from other machines, set ROOT_LOGIN_REMOTE to "yes". (Logging in via ssh is not affected by this variable since SSH is seen as a safe login method). </para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Values</title> <para> yes or no </para> </refsect2>

console_shutdown.description:
<para>
determines how ctrl-alt-del is handled.
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Values</title> <para>
ignore, reboot or halt
</para> </refsect2>

cwd_in_root_path.purpose: Do you want to have dot in root path?
cwd_in_root_path.description:
<para>
Do you want to have a dot in root path? This is not recommended, but many people do prefer it (yes/no). The setting affects all system users (with uid < 100)
</para> <refsect2> <title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Values</title> <para>
yes or no
</para> </refsect2>

faillog_enab.purpose: Enable logging and display of /var/log/faillog login failure info.
faillog_enab.description:
<para> Enable logging and display of <filename>/var/log/faillog</filename> login failure info. </para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Values</title> <para>
yes or no
</para> </refsect2>

fail_delay.purpose: Delay in seconds before being allowed another attempt after a login failure
fail_delay.description:
<para>
Delay in seconds before being allowed another attempt after a login failure
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Values</title> <para>
number representing seconds.
</para> </refsect2>

gid_max.purpose: Min/max values for automatic gid selection in groupadd
gid_max.description:
<para>
Min/max values for automatic gid selection in groupadd
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2>

gid_min.purpose: Min/max values for automatic gid selection in groupadd
gid_min.description:
<para>
Min/max values for automatic gid selection in groupadd
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2>

uid_max.purpose: Min/max values for automatic uid selection in useradd
uid_max.description:
<para>
Min/max values for automatic uid selection in useradd
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2>

uid_min.purpose: Min/max values for automatic uid selection in useradd
uid_min.description:
<para>
Min/max values for automatic uid selection in useradd
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2>

kdm_shutdown.purpose: who will be able to shutdown the system in kdm
kdm_shutdown.description:
<para> Determines who will be able to shutdown the system in kdm.
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Values</title> <para>
"root", "all", "none", "local", "auto"
</para> </refsect2>

lastlog_enab.purpose: Enable logging and display of /var/log/lastlog login time info.
lastlog_enab.description:
<para> Enable logging and display of /var/log/lastlog login time info.
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Values</title> <para>
yes or no
</para> </refsect2>

md5_support.description:
<para> Activate MD5 encryption for passwords
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Values</title> <para>
yes or no
</para> </refsect2>

obscure_changes_enab.purpose: Enable additional checks upon password changes.
obscure_changes_enab.description:
<para>
Enable additional checks upon password changes.
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Values</title> <para>
yes or no
</para> </refsect2>

passwd_use_cracklib.description:
<para>
Use Cracklib
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Values</title> <para>
yes or no
</para> </refsect2>

pass_max_days.purpose: Maximum number of days a password may be used.
pass_max_days.description:
<para>
Maximum number of days a password may be used.
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Values</title> <para>
Number
</para> </refsect2>

pass_min_days.purpose: Minimum number of days allowed between password changes.
pass_min_days.description:
<para>
Minimum number of days allowed between password changes.
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Values</title> <para>
Number
</para> </refsect2>

pass_min_len.description:
<para>
Minimum acceptable password length. </para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Values</title> <para>
Number
</para> </refsect2>

pass_warn_age.purpose: Number of days warning given before a password expires.
pass_warn_age.description:
<para>
Number of days warning given before a password expires.
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Values</title> <para>
Number
</para> </refsect2>

permission_security.description:
<para>
&company-suse; Linux contains two different configurations for chkstat. The differences can be found in <filename>/etc/permissions.secure</filename> and <filename>/etc/permissions.easy</filename>. If you create your own configuration (e.g. permissions.foo), you can enter the extension here as well.
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Values</title> <para> easy/secure local foo whateveryouwant
</para> </refsect2>

run_updatedb_as.purpose: Which user should updatedb use to run?
run_updatedb_as.description:
<para> updatedb has a parameter "--localuser". It runs the "find" command as this user. Some people think this is a security hole if set to 'root' (because some directory information can be read which is normally protected). Others think it is useful to hold all files in the database. So if you want full information in locate db, set RUN_UPDATEDB_AS to root. If you want security use RUN_UPDATEDB_AS with nobody.
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Values</title> <para> user name
</para> </refsect2>

activate.purpose: activate partition where LILO is installed
activate.description:
<para> activate partition where LILO is installed. Set this option to true to mark the partition as active. Usually this is not required, but, on some systems, the BIOS only boots from an active partition.
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Values</title> <para> boolean: true or false
</para> </refsect2>

linear.description:
<para> Generate linear sector addresses instead of sector/head/cylinder addresses. Linear addresses are translated at run time and do not depend on disk geometry. When using `linear' with large disks, <command>/sbin/lilo</command> may generate references to inaccessible disk areas, because 3D sector addresses are not known before boot time. 'lba32' avoids many of these pitfalls with its use of packet addressing, but requires a recent BIOS. (See man lilo.conf(5))
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Values</title> <para> boolean: true or false
</para> </refsect2>

location.description:
<para> Sets the name of the device (e.g. a hard disk partition) that contains the boot sector. If <emphasis>mbr</emphasis> is given, lilo will be written on the MBR disk.
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Values</title> <para> mbr, floppy or a partition device (or a hard drive device)
</para> </refsect2>

parameters.description:
<para>
Appends the options specified to the parameter line passed to the kernel. This is typically used to specify parameters of hardware that can't be entirely auto-detected or for which probing may be dangerous.
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Values</title> <para> kernel parameters, i.e. "enableapic hdb=ide-scsi" (without the quotes)
</para> </refsect2>

confirm.description:
<para> Confirm installation before anything is done on the system. This is to avoid any recrusive installations.
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Values</title> <para> boolean, true by default.
</para> </refsect2>

users.description:
<para> Using this resource, you will be able to add users to the system. This resource is also used to set the root password.
</para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Resource </para> </refsect2>

user.description: <para> This resource contains data about a single user that should be added to the system. </para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Resource </para> </refsect2>

username.description: <para> The user name, or login </para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> string, use <emphasis>lowercase</emphasis> letters (no accented characters), digits, and <emphasis>._-</emphasis> User names have stricter restrictions than passwords! </para> </refsect2>

user_password.description: <para> A password should have at least 5 characters and, as a rule, not contain any special characters (e.g., accented characters). </para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Value</title> <para> valid password </para> </refsect2>

home.description:
<para>The home directory of the user. Normally this is /home/username.
</para> <refsect2> <title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Value</title> <para> string, example <filename>/home/nashif</filename> </para> </refsect2>

gid.description:
<para> In addition to its name, a group has to be assigned a numerical ID for its internal representation. These values are between 0 and a value defined in <filename>/etc/login.defs</filename>. Some of the IDs are already assigned during installation.
</para> <para> Leave empty if unsure, &yast2; will determine the value automatically. </para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Value</title> <para> string </para> </refsect2>

uid.description:
<para> Each user is known to the system by a unique number, the "User ID". For normal users, you should use a UID bigger than the value defined in the system, because the smaller UIDs are used by the system for special purposes and pseudo logins.
</para> <para> Leave empty if unsure, &yast2; will determine the value automatically. </para> <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Value</title> <para> string </para> </refsect2>

shell.purpose: The login shell (command interpreter) for the user.
shell.description:
<para> Select one shell from the list of all shells installed on your system. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Value</title> <para> string </para> </refsect2>

grouplist.description:
<para> All additional memberships in groups for the user. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Value</title> <para> comma seprated values </para> </refsect2>

min_hsync.description:
<para> The <emphasis>horizontal frequency</emphasis> (in kHz) specifies how many times per second the monitor can write a horizontal scan line. This is a hard limit of the monitor, independent of the screen resolution. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Value</title> <para> integer </para> </refsect2>

max_hsync.description:
<para> The <emphasis>horizontal frequency</emphasis> (in kHz) specifies how many times per second the monitor can write a horizontal scan line. This is a hard limit of the monitor, independent of the screen resolution. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Value</title> <para> integer </para> </refsect2>

max_vsync.description:
<para> The <emphasis>vertical frequency</emphasis> (in Hz) specifies how many times per second the image on the screen is refreshed. This value depends on the screen resolution and the monitor's maximum horizontal frequency. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Value</title> <para> integer </para> </refsect2>

min_vsync.description:
<para> The <emphasis>vertical frequency</emphasis> (in Hz) specifies how many times per second the image on the screen is refreshed. This value depends on the screen resolution and the monitor's maximum horizontal frequency.
</para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Value</title> <para> integer </para> </refsect2>

display_manager.description:
<para> What display manager to install </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Value</title> <para> string: kdm or gdm </para> </refsect2>

enable_3d.description:
<para> Enable 3D support for X11. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Value</title> <para> boolean: true or false </para> </refsect2>

resolution.description:
<para> Configure X11 Resolution. &yast2; will by default add all lower resolution up to the selected one. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Value</title> <para> 640x480, 800x600, 1024x768, 1152x864, 1280x960, 1280x1024, 1600x1200 </para> </refsect2>

aliases.description:
<para> This table redirects mail delivered locally. Redirect it to another local user (useful for system accounts, especially for root), to a remote address, or to a list of addresses. See the aliases(5) manual page for a description of advanced features.
</para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> List Resource </para> </refsect2>

mta.description:
<para> Mail transport agent to use </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Value</title> <para> string: sendmail or postfix </para> </refsect2>

alias_entry.description:
<para> A single mail alias entry </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Resource </para>

alias.description:
<para> Alias for incoming mail redirection </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Value</title> <para> string </para> </refsect2>

from_header.description:
<para> You may want the mail you sent to appear as if it originated from company.com instead of pc-042.company.com. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Value</title> <para> string: domain name </para> </refsect2>

local_domains.description:
<para> specify the domains for which the mail will be delivered locally. If you enter nothing, the local host name is assumed. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> List Property </para> </refsect2>

outgoing_mail_server.description:
<para> The outgoing mail server is generally intended for dial-up connections. Enter the Internet service provider's SMTP server, such as smtp.provider.com. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Value</title> <para> string: valid smtp server name </para> </refsect2>

use_amavis.description:
<para> Use a virus scanner (AMaViS), amavis-sendmail or amavis-postfix must be installed. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Value</title> <para> boolean: true or false </para> </refsect2>

connection_type.description:
<para> How are you connected to the Internet? </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Value</title> <para> string: permanent, dialup or none </para> </refsect2>

networking.description:
<para> Configure interfaces, DNS and routing </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Resource </para> </refsect2>

interfaces.description:
<para> A List of network interfaces available in the system. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> List Resource </para> </refsect2>

startmode.purpose: Boot mode of a network interface
startmode.description:
<para> Configure the boot mode of a network interface. This property describes the mode of the device setup, missing means "onboot" </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> onboot|hotplug|manual </para> </refsect2>

bootproto.purpose: Boot protocol of a network interface
bootproto.description:
<para> Configure the boot protocol of a network interface. This property describes the setup protocol, if missing or "none", fixed address is used </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> none|bootp|dhcp </para> </refsect2>

ipaddr.description:
<para> IP4 address </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> valid ipv4 address </para> </refsect2>

netmask.description:
<para> Configure network interface Netmas </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property (NETMASK) </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> valid netmask, i.e. 255.255.255.0 </para> </refsect2>

network.description:
<para> Configure network interface Netmask </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> valid netmask, i.e. 255.255.255.0 </para> </refsect2>

broadcast.description:
<para> Configure network interface broadcast </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> valid broadcast value , i.e. 10.10.0.255 </para> </refsect2>

device.purpose: Network device name or harddisk device
device.description:
<itemizedlist> <listitem> <para> Network device name. </para> </listitem> <listitem> <para> Harddisk device </para> </listitem> </itemizedlist>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Shared property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2> <title>Value</title> <para> <emphasis>eth</emphasis> or <emphasis>tr</emphasis> with device number or a valid hard disk device, i.e. <emphasis>/dev/hda</emphasis> </para> </refsect2>

dhcp_hostname.description:
<para> Set hostname using DHCP </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> boolean: true or false </para> </refsect2>

domain.description:
<para> set domain name </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> valid domain name </para> </refsect2>

hostname.description:
<para> set hostname </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> valid host name </para> </refsect2>

nameservers.description:
<para> Configure a list of nameservers to be used </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> List Resource </para> </refsect2>

nameserver.description:
<para> Configure a nameserver to be used </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> valid nameserver name </para> </refsect2>

searchlist.description:
<para> Configure a list of domains to search first </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> List Resource </para> </refsect2>

search.description:
<para> Configure the domains to be searched </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> valid search entry (domain name) </para> </refsect2>

routing.description:
<para> configure alist of routing destinations </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Resource </para> </refsect2>

route.description:
<para> Add a route entry to the routing list. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Resource </para> </refsect2>

destination.purpose: Destination for mail aliases or destination of a routing entry
destination.description:
<itemizedlist> <listitem> <para> Routing entry destination </para> </listitem> <listitem> <para> Destination of an alias for incoming mail. </para> </listitem> </itemizedlist>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Shared Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> string </para> </refsect2>

software.description:
<para> Configure Software selections and packages </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Resource </para> </refsect2>

base.description:
<para> Base software selection </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> A software selection name as described in table <link linkend="StandardSL" endterm="StandardSL.title"></link> </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>&alice; Compatibility</title> <para>This property is replaces the following tags in &alice; </para> <itemizedlist> <listitem><para><SYS_SW_SELECTION></para><para>Only the name of the selection is required. The extention <emphasis>.sel</emphasis> should be ommited.</para></listitem> </itemizedlist>
</refsect2>

addon.description:
<para> Add-on software selection </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2>
<refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> A software selection name as described in table <link linkend="StandardSL" endterm="StandardSL.title"></link> </para> </refsect2>

packages.purpose: A list of packages to install
packages.description:
<para> A list of packages to install </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> List Resource </para> </refsect2>

package.purpose: Packages that are not part of any selections and custom packages
package.description:
<para> Add Packages that are not part of any selections and custom packages. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2>
<refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> A package name available in in the package repository. </para> </refsect2>

chroot-scripts.purpose: A list of post-install scripts (Chroot environment)
chroot-scripts.description:
<para> A list of scripts that get executed before the system boots for the first time and before the actual system is mounted, hence chroot </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> List Resource </para> </refsect2>

pre-scripts.description:
<para> A list of scripts that get executed before the system is installed. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> List Resource </para> </refsect2>

post-scripts.description:
<para> A list of scripts that get executed after the system is installed. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> List Resource </para> </refsect2>

script.purpose: A custom shell or perl script
script.description:
<para> Custom scripts can be executed in 3 different stages of the installation to give the user maximum flexibility configuring the system. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Shared Resource </para> </refsect2>

source.purpose: Source of a custom shell or perl script
source.description:
<para> Custom scripts can be executed in 3 different stages of the installation to give the user maximum flexibility configuring the system. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> CDATA Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> Source code of a custom script. Source must be included in CDATA tags. </para> </refsect2>

filename.purpose: File name of a custom user script
filename.description:
<para> Name of the script file </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> Unique string </para> </refsect2>

interpreter.purpose: The interpreter to be used with a specific script
interpreter.description:
<para> Perl scripts can only be used in post-install. Shell scripts can be used throughout the entire installation. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> perl or shell </para> </refsect2>

partitioning.purpose: Resource controlling partitioning of hard drives
partitioning.description:
<para> A List of drives with partition data and partitioning behaviour. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> List Resource </para> </refsect2>

drive.description:
<para> A List of drives with partition data and partitioning behaviour. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Resource </para> </refsect2>

partitions.purpose: List of partitions in a drive
partitions.description:
<para> A List of partitions in a drive. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> List Resource </para> </refsect2>

use.purpose: Determine how to handle existing partitions on a target drive
use.description:
<para> Determine how to handle existing partitions on a target drive </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> all, free, or a list of partition numbers to be used for the installation. </para> </refsect2>

crypt_fs.purpose: Determine if a specific partition should be encrypted
crypt_fs.description:
<para> Determine if a specific partition should be encrypted </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> boolean </para> </refsect2>

crypt_key.purpose: Crypt key for a crypted filesystem
crypt_key.description:
<para> Set the crypt key for a file system. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> string </para> </refsect2>

files.description:
<para> List of files tp be copied into the target system. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> List Resource </para> </refsect2>

config_file.purpose: Copy a complete configuration file to target system
config_file.description:
<para> This resource lets you define a configuration file to be copied or dumped into the the target system. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Resource </para> </refsect2>

file_contents.description:
<para> The source of a configuration file. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> CDATA Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> Any data </para> </refsect2>

file_path.purpose: The location of the configuration file
file_path.description:
<para> Define where to copy a configuration file in the target system. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> String representing a path. </para> </refsect2>

runlevels.description:
<para> Configure what runlevel should the system boot to and what services should be started. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Resource </para> </refsect2>

services.description:
<para> Configure what services should be started. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> List Resource </para> </refsect2>

service.description:
<para> Configure in what runlevels should a services be started or stopped. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Resource </para> </refsect2>

default.description:
<para> Define the default runlevel. </para> <para>As specifed in <filename>/etc/inittab</filename>, the following run levels are possible</para> <screen> # runlevel 0 is System halt (Do not use this for initdefault!) # runlevel 1 is Single user mode # runlevel 2 is Local multiuser without remote network (e.g. NFS) # runlevel 3 is Full multiuser with network # runlevel 4 is Not used # runlevel 5 is Full multiuser with network and xdm # runlevel 6 is System reboot (Do not use this for initdefault!) </screen>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> A number representing the runlevel. </para> </refsect2>

service_name.description:
<para> Service name. Normally this is the name of a script available in <filename>/etc/init.d</filename>. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> String, service must be available in <filename>/etc/init.d</filename> </para> </refsect2>

service_start.purpose: Runlevels to start a service in
service_start.description:
<para> A space seperated list of runlevels this service should be started in. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> String (Space seperated list of numbers) </para> </refsect2>

service_stop.purpose: Runlevels to stop a service in
service_stop.description:
<para> A space seperated list of runlevels this service should be stopped in. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> String (Space seperated list of numbers) </para> </refsect2>

encryption_method.description:
<para> <emphasis>DES</emphasis>, the Linux default method, works in all network environments, but it restricts you to passwords no longer than eight characters. <emphasis>MD5</emphasis> allows longer passwords, thus provides more security, but some network protocols don't support this, and you may have problems with NIS. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> &des; or &md5;, default is &md5; </para> </refsect2>

ldap.purpose: Authenticate users with an OpenLDAP server
ldap.description:
<para> Using this resource, the target machine can be set up as a <emphasis>LDAP client</emphasis> to authenticate users with an OpenLDAP server. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Resource </para> </refsect2>

ldap_domain.description:
<para> Enter the name of the search base (base DN, e.g, dc=mydomain,dc=com) </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> base DN, e.g, dc=mydomain,dc=com </para> </refsect2>

ldap_server.description:
<para>IP address of the LDAP server </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> IP address. </para> </refsect2>

ldap_v2.description:
<para>Normally, the &ldap; version 3 protocol will be used. If you have a &ldap; server using protocol 2 (for example &openldap; v1), you should activate <emphasis>&ldap; Version 2</emphasis> </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> IP address. </para> </refsect2>

nis.purpose: Authenticate users with a NIS server

nfs_entry.description:
<para> One &nfs; entry to be added in thr <filename>/etc/fstab</filename> file. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Resource </para> </refsect2>

nfs_options.description:
<para>Options for a &nfs; entry as described in the <emphasis>fstab(5)</emphasis> man page. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> Valid options as described in <emphasis>fstab(5)</emphasis> </para> </refsect2>

server_path.description: <refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> Network path for the exported file system (i.e. 192.168.1.1:/exported) </para> </refsect2>

nis_server.description:
<para>&ip; address of the ⋼ server </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> &ip; address. </para> </refsect2>

nisplus_server.description:
<para>&ip; address of the &nisplus; server </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> &ip; address. </para> </refsect2>

nis_domain.description:
<para> Enter the name of the ⋼ domain, i.e. host.com </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> Valid domain name </para> </refsect2>

nis_servers.description:
<para>&ip; addresses of the ⋼ servers </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> List Resource </para> </refsect2>

start_autofs.description:
<para> Automounter is a daemon that mounts directories automatically. It is assumed that its configuration files (auto.*) already exist, either locally or over ⋼.
</para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> Boolean </para> </refsect2>

nisplus_domain.description:
<para> Enter the name of the &nisplus; domain, i.e. host.com </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> Valid domain name </para> </refsect2>

extra_packages.purpose: Packages that are not part of SuSE Linux
extra_packages.description:
<para> This resource lets you add packages which are not part of &company-suse; Linux. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Resource </para> </refsect2>

kernel.purpose: Specify a kernel package different than the standard
kernel.description:
<para> Specify a kernel package different than the standard </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> String (Package name without the .rpm extension) </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>&alice; Compatibility</title> <para>This property is replaces the following tags in &alice; </para> <itemizedlist> <listitem><para><SYS_INST_KERNEL></para></listitem> </itemizedlist>
</refsect2>

package_location.purpose: Location of non-SuSE packages on installation medium
package_location.description:
<para> Location of the extra package. This directory should be available in the same directory where all other RPMs are, in <filename>suse</filename> sub-directory of the installation root. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> String </para> </refsect2>

filesystem.purpose: File system used for a certain partition
filesystem.description:
<para> Define which type of filesystem should be used on a certain partition. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> reiser, jfs, xfs, ext2, ext3. </para> </refsect2>

mount.description:
<para> Define the mount point of a partition during installation. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> Valid string representing a mountpoint (i.e. <filename>/local</filename>) </para> </refsect2>

size.description:
<para> Set the size of a partition. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> Size in MB or GB, i.e. 1gb or 1500mb. </para> </refsect2>

mount_point.purpose: Mount point for a NFS entry
mount_point.description:
<para> Define the mount point of a NFS entry </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> Valid string representing a mountpoint (i.e. <filename>/local</filename>) </para> </refsect2>

module.purpose: Kernel module of a netwrok interface
module.description:
<para> Kernel module of a netwrok interface </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> String representing a kernel module for a network interface. </para> </refsect2>

filesystem_id.purpose: File system ID used for a certain partition
filesystem_id.description:
<para> Define which filesystem ID should be used on a certain partition. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> The id f the file system as can be seen in <command>fdisk</command> </para> </refsect2>

format.purpose: Specify if a certain partition should be formatted
format.description:
<para>Specify if a certain partition should be formatted
</para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> Boolean value </para> </refsect2>

gateway.description:
<para> Configure a gateway for routing IP trafic </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> IP of a gateway </para> </refsect2>

sysconfig.description:
<para> Use this resource to set syscofnig variables in <filename>/etc/sysconfig</filename> </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> List Resource </para> </refsect2>

sysconfig_entry.description:
<para> Use this resource to set syscofnig variable in <filename>/etc/sysconfig</filename> </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Resource </para> </refsect2>

sysconfig_key.description:
<para> The key of a sysconfig variable or the variable itself </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> Any variable defined in a sysconfig file in <filename>/etc/sysconfig</filename> </para> </refsect2>

sysconfig_value.description:
<para> The value of a sysconfig variable </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> Any value and according to specification defined in the sysconfig file.li </para> </refsect2>

sysconfig_path.description:
<para> The path to a sysconfig file relative to <filename>/etc/sysconfig</filename> </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> File path relative to <filename>/etc/sysconfig</filename> </para> </refsect2>

logical_volumes.description:
<para> Configure LVM logical volumes. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> List Resource </para> </refsect2>

lv_fs.purpose: File system of a LVM logical volume
lv_fs.description:
<para> File system to use on a LVM logical volume. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> One of the following: ext2, ext3, reiser, jfs or xfs </para> </refsect2>

lv_mount.purpose: Mount point of a LVM logical volume
lv_mount.description:
<para> Mount point of a LVM logical volume. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> Valid mount point. </para> </refsect2>

lv_name.purpose: Name of a LVM logical volume
lv_name.description:
<para> Name of a LVM logical volume. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> Name of the volume, i.e. <emphasis>optlv</emphasis> </para> </refsect2>

lv_size.purpose: Size of a LVM logical volume
lv_size.description:
<para> Size of a LVM logical volume. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> Size of the volume, i.e. <emphasis>2gb</emphasis> or <emphasis>1500mb</emphasis> </para> </refsect2>

lvm_name.description:
<para> Name of a LVM Group. </para>
<refsect2><title>Type</title> <para> Property </para> </refsect2> <refsect2><title>Value</title> <para> Normally called <emphasis>System</emphasis> </para> </refsect2>
